awd_titl_txt: Dynamical System Approach in Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of this project is to study dynamical behavior of special solutions for some hyperbolic type partial differential equations (PDEs), which include nonlinear wave equation, nonlinear Schrodinger equation and compressible Euler equation. These equations  are  widely used to model various problems arising from physics, engineering, biology, finance, etc. The PI aims to construct certain special solutions for those aforementioned equations and their perturbations to understand the modeled phenomena. The perturbations considered in this project have either different scales or  randomness,  which requires new mathematical ideas and tools to handle. The successfully constructed solutions will not only provide new theoretical results but also stimulate efficient numerical algorithms to compute solutions in multi-scale and stochastic dynamical systems. 

More specifically, the PI intends to study the following problems rigorously. The first category of problems is to construct special dynamical structures for three kinds of hyperbolic PDEs, which include a system of nonlinear wave equations, the cubic focusing Schrodinger equation and quasilinear Schrodinger equation in high dimensions. All these problems have multiple spatio-temporal scales, which requires new mathematical ideas and analytical tools to handle. The next problem is to study the persistence of Sine-Gordon breather under multiplicative noise perturbation. The main aim is to understand the effect of stochastic forcing. A new method stemming from invariant manifold, random dynamical system and ergodic theory needs to be developed. The last problem in this project is to study the asymptotic behavior of solutions near some steady states for isentropic and non-isentropic compressible flows by using ideas of invariant manifold. The PI will extend existing ideas and develop techniques both on geometric and analytic aspects to provide not only a solution but also a new perspective of this problem.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to employ ideas and analytic tools from dynamical system to study the dynamical structure of infinite dimensional system mainly generated by PDEs. Under the NSF support,  Shen together with her collaborators accomplished 15 research works on the following six dynamical aspects: 1) asymptotic dynamics of chemotaxis models with logistic source on bounded domains; 2) spatial spreading and front propagation dynamics of chemotaxis models with logistic source on unbounded doamins; 3) persistence, spreading speeds, and forced propagation profiles of species governed by Keller-Segel chemoattraction systems in shifting environments; 4) spreading-vanishing dynamics in logistic type chemotaxis models in one space dimension with a free boundary; 5) long time behavior of Fisher-KPP equations with random perturbations on the growth rate and carrying capacity, and 6) asymptotic dynamics of scalar reaction-diffusion equations on $S^1$ or R with time periodic or almost periodic dependence. 

The intellectual merit:  Several new and interesting results on the asymptotic dynamics in chemotaxis models in various types of environments  and in reaction diffusion equations in heterogeneous and random media are obtained in the works accomplished under the NSF support. For example,  we proved that, under proper conditions, any globally defined positive solution of a chemotaxis model with linear sensitivity and logistic source in a bounded environment is pointwise persistenct, i.e., it is bounded below by a positive constant independent of its initial condition when the time is large enough. In literature, the persistence of mass for globally defined positive solutions was established, which indicates that the population as a whole always persists. The pointwise persistence we proved implies that not only the population as a whole persists but also it persists at any location eventually. We proved that, in any space dimensional setting, a logistic soruce is sufficient to enforce the global existence of classical solutions of chemotaxis models with any singular sensitivity. In literature, such results have only been proved in the two-dimensional setting. We proved the existence of a minimal wave speed $c_*$ for the traveling wave solutions of a full parabolic Keller-Segel chemotaxis system with logistic source in the whole space, i.e., the system has a traveling wave solution with speed c for any c greater than or equal to $c_*$ and has no traveling wave solutions with speed less than$ c_*$. We proved, under some natural assumption, that the chemotaxis neither speeds up, nor slows down the spatial spreading in a parabolic-elliptic Keller-Segel system with logistic source. 

The works accomplished under the NSF support have made important contributions to the understanding of the complicated dynamics in chemotaxis models and in reaction diffusion equations in heterogeneous and random media. Several useful methods have also been developed in the works under the support.

Broader of impacts: The research works supported by the NSF have provided some biological insights into the understanding of the population dynamics of a species governed by chemotaxis models with linear sensitivity or singular sensitivity in various environments. For example, in a parabolic-elliptic chemotaxis model with logistic source in the whole space, it is observed that the chemotaxis neither speeds up, nor slows down the spatial spreading provided that the logistic damping is large relative to the chemotaxis sensitivity, and the degradation rate of the chemical substance is larger than the intrinsic growth rate of the mobile species. In a parabolic-elliptic chemotaxis model with logistic source in a shifting environment, it is observed that if the speed of the underlying shifting environment is too large, then the species becomes extinct in the habitat eventually. It is observed that finite-time blow-up is prevented by a logistic source in chemotaxis models with singular sensitivity in any dimensional setting.  The research works supported by the NSF grant have had some important impacts on some graduates' and junior faculty's research. They have also provided research opportunities to those who are interested in partial differential equations, in particular, various chemotaxis systems.



Last Modified: 09/05/2021
Modified by: Wenxian Shen
